title: 111_s1412
content: The "Commodity Speculation Reform Act of 2009" allows the Commodity Futures Trading Commission to issue no-action letters. The Commodity Exchange Act is amended to allow the Commission to issue no action letters to foreign boards of trade, with certain exceptions. The Commodity Exchange Act is amended to allow the Commission to issue no action letters to foreign boards of trade, with comparable information and data accessibility. The Commodity Exchange Act is amended to address excessive speculation in commodity futures contracts and financial instruments. The Commodity Exchange Act is amended to address excessive speculation in commodity futures contracts and financial instruments by adding provisions related to the treatment of purchases of certain commodity futures contracts and financial instruments. The Commodity Exchange Act is amended to address excessive speculation in commodity futures contracts and financial instruments by adding provisions related to the treatment of purchases of certain commodity futures contracts and financial instruments. The amendments aim to reduce risks in commercial enterprises and are economically appropriate. Assets are what a person owns, produces, manufactures, possesses, or merchandises, while liabilities are what a person incurs or anticipates incurring. Services refer to the activities that a person provides or purchases. The term 'bona fide hedging transaction' excludes transactions on a designated contract market to offset financial risks from over-the-counter commodity derivatives traded or held in the United States. The term 'bona fide hedging transaction' excludes certain options not traded on designated markets, involving commodities or financial indices. The term 'bona fide hedging transaction' involves executing payments based on qualifying commodities or financial indices to transfer economic risk without conveying ownership. The term 'over-the-counter commodity derivative dealer' refers to a person regularly engaging in transactions related to agreements, contracts, or options involving financial risks without conveying ownership. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission will establish regulations within 90 days to oversee the offset, assignment, or termination of positions in agricultural and energy commodities with customers in the ordinary course of business. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission will establish and enforce speculative position limits for qualifying commodities, along with a methodology to aggregate positions held or controlled by individuals across different markets and ensure accurate determinations. The Commission will enforce position limits for qualifying commodities and establish information reporting rules to monitor and enforce these limits effectively. The Commission will enforce position limits for qualifying commodities, including monitoring positions in over-the-counter commodity derivatives. Position limits established shall apply to positions expiring during the spot month, each separate futures trading month (excluding the spot month), or the sum of each. The speculative position limits apply to the sum of positions held by a person on designated contract markets, derivatives transaction execution facilities, and in over-the-counter commodity derivatives. The Commission sets speculative position limits at the minimum level necessary for market liquidity for hedging activities. Prohibition on holding net long or net short positions for future commodity delivery. The Commission sets speculative position limits to ensure market liquidity for hedging activities. These limits apply to futures, options, and over-the-counter commodity derivatives exceeding the limit. Bona fide hedging transactions are not included in determining if a position exceeds the limit. The position of an over-the-counter commodity derivative dealer is calculated monthly as the average daily net position held or controlled by the dealer. The position of an over-the-counter commodity derivative dealer is calculated monthly based on the average daily net position held or controlled by the dealer.
